sections.title: Source Files
sections.content:
Source Files

 ZeroWidthNoBreakSpace ::=
 $$\u{FEFF}$$

 Shebang ::=
 $$#!$$ ~[NewLine]*

 NewLine ::=
 $$\n$$

A source file contains the program text consisting of [inner
attribute]s, [inner doc comment]s, and [item]s. The location of a
source file is tool defined.

A Shebang does not have an effect on the compilation.

paragraphs.fls_4vicosdeaqmp: A source file contains the program text consisting of [inner attribute]s, [inner doc comment]s, and [item]s. The location of a source file is tool defined.
paragraphs.fls_ann3cha1xpek: A Shebang does not have an effect on the compilation.

paragraphs.syntax_1:
SourceFile ::=
       ZeroWidthNoBreakSpace?
       Shebang?
       InnerAttributeOrDoc*
       Item*

   ZeroWidthNoBreakSpace ::=
       $$\u{FEFF}$$

   Shebang ::=
       $$#!$$ ~[NewLine]*

   NewLine ::=
       $$\n$$

sections.title: Modules
sections.content:
Modules

 ModuleSpecification ::=
 InlineModuleSpecification
 | OutlineModuleSpecification

 InlineModuleSpecification ::=
 $${$$
 InnerAttributeOrDoc*
 Item*
 $$}$$

 OutlineModuleSpecification ::=
 $$;$$

A module is a container for zero or more [item]s.

The unsafe keyword of a module is rejected, but may still
be consumed by [macro]s.

An inline module is a module with an InlineModuleSpecification.

An outline module is a module with an OutlineModuleSpecification.

An outline module loads a source file and considers the text of the
source file to be inlined within the context of the outline module.

The location of a module source file can be specified using
attribute path.

paragraphs.fls_odd1hj3y1mgu: A module is a container for zero or more [item]s.
paragraphs.fls_whgv72emrm47: The unsafe keyword of a module is rejected, but may still be consumed by [macro]s.
paragraphs.fls_qypjjpcf8uwq: An inline module is a module with an InlineModuleSpecification.
paragraphs.fls_cavwpr1ybk37: An outline module is a module with an OutlineModuleSpecification.
paragraphs.fls_plepew2319g4: An outline module loads a source file and considers the text of the source file to be inlined within the context of the outline module.
paragraphs.fls_1aruwps62c4p: The location of a module source file can be specified using attribute path.

paragraphs.syntax_1:
ModuleDeclaration ::=
       $$unsafe$$? $$mod$$ Name ModuleSpecification

   ModuleSpecification ::=
       InlineModuleSpecification
     | OutlineModuleSpecification

   InlineModuleSpecification ::=
       $${$$
         InnerAttributeOrDoc*
         Item*
       $$}$$

   OutlineModuleSpecification ::=
       $$;$$

sections.title: Crates
sections.content:
Crates

A crate is a unit of compilation and linking that contains a tree of
nested [module]s.

The crate type of a crate is the value of the attribute
crate_type of a crate or the value of --crate-type flag passed to
the tool compiling the crate.

The crate type of a crate if not specified is bin.

A crate may be subject to multiple [crate type]s, treating each type
as a separate crate.

A binary crate is a crate whose crate type is bin.

A binary crate that is not subject to attribute no_main shall have
a function in scope of its crate root module under the name
main with a main function signature.

The function in scope of a binary crate's crate root module under
the name main with a main function signature is the binary
crate's program entry point.

A library crate is a crate whose crate type is lib, rlib,
staticlib, dylib, or cdylib.

A proc-macro crate is a crate whose crate type is proc-macro.

A proc-macro crate shall not declare [item]s in its crate root
module with public visibility unless the item is a procedural
macro.

Only a proc-macro crate shall declare [procedural macro]s.

paragraphs.fls_qwghk79ok5h0: A crate is a unit of compilation and linking that contains a tree of nested [module]s.
paragraphs.fls_unxalgMqIr3v: The crate type of a crate is the value of the attribute crate_type of a crate or the value of --crate-type flag passed to the tool compiling the crate.
paragraphs.fls_e7jGvXvTsFpC: The crate type of a crate if not specified is bin.
paragraphs.fls_kQiJPwb2Hjcc: A crate may be subject to multiple [crate type]s, treating each type as a separate crate.
paragraphs.fls_9ub6ks8qrang: A binary crate is a crate whose crate type is bin.
paragraphs.fls_OyFwBtDGVimT: A binary crate that is not subject to attribute no_main shall have a function in scope of its crate root module under the name main with a main function signature.
paragraphs.fls_jQqXxPyND1ds: The function in scope of a binary crate's crate root module under the name main with a main function signature is the binary crate's program entry point.
paragraphs.fls_d9nn4yuiw1ja: A library crate is a crate whose crate type is lib, rlib, staticlib, dylib, or cdylib.
paragraphs.fls_Mf62VqAhoZ3c: A proc-macro crate is a crate whose crate type is proc-macro.
paragraphs.fls_RJJmN4tP7j4m: A proc-macro crate shall not declare [item]s in its crate root module with public visibility unless the item is a procedural macro.
paragraphs.fls_h93C3wfbAoz1: Only a proc-macro crate shall declare [procedural macro]s.

sections.title: Crate Imports
sections.content:
Crate Imports

 CrateIndication ::=
 Identifier
 | $$self$$

A crate import specifies a required dependency on an external crate.

A crate indication is a construct that indicates a crate.

A crate import binds an external crate to its crate indication.

Crate indication self shall require a renaming.

A crate import with a renaming with an identifier binds the
external crate to a local name and introduces the local name into
the enclosing scope.

If a crate import appears at the crate root module, then the
crate indication is added to the external prelude.

A crate indication shall resolve to an external crate. The process of
resolving a crate indication to an external crate is tool-defined.

paragraphs.fls_d0pa807s5d5h: A crate import specifies a required dependency on an external crate.
paragraphs.fls_vfam3wzeAiah: A crate indication is a construct that indicates a crate.
paragraphs.fls_ft860vkz0lkc: A crate import binds an external crate to its crate indication.
paragraphs.fls_k90qtnf8kgu1: Crate indication self shall require a renaming.
paragraphs.fls_siv8bl6s2ndu: A crate import with a renaming with an identifier binds the external crate to a local name and introduces the local name into the enclosing scope.
paragraphs.fls_7vz5n3x6jo1s: If a crate import appears at the crate root module, then the crate indication is added to the external prelude.
paragraphs.fls_3bgpc8m8yk4p: A crate indication shall resolve to an external crate. The process of resolving a crate indication to an external crate is tool-defined.

sections.title: Compilation Roots
sections.content:
Compilation Roots

A crate root module is the root of the nested module tree of a
crate.

A tool can define a crate root module for a single crate.

A compilation root is an input to a compilation performed by a tool. A
crate root module is a compilation root.

paragraphs.fls_fhiqvgdamq5: A crate root module is the root of the nested module tree of a crate.
paragraphs.fls_tk8tl2e0a34: A tool can define a crate root module for a single crate.
paragraphs.fls_bsyfxdk3ap1t: A compilation root is an input to a compilation performed by a tool. A crate root module is a compilation root.

sections.title: Conditional Compilation
sections.content:
Conditional Compilation

Conditionally-compiled source code is source code that may or may
not be considered a part of a Rust program depending on
[configuration predicate]s.

Conditional compilation is the process of compiling
conditionally-compiled source code.

A construct subject to attribute cfg where the related
configuration predicate evaluates to false is not considered part of a
Rust program.

A crate root module subject to attribute cfg where the related
configuration predicate evaluates to false is considered empty except
for all [attribute]s up to the invoked attribute cfg.

An attribute cfg_attr where the related configuration predicate
evaluates to false is not considered part of a Rust program.

paragraphs.fls_9stc6nul6vq9: Conditionally-compiled source code is source code that may or may not be considered a part of a Rust program depending on [configuration predicate]s.
paragraphs.fls_a0u9nnaf6drz: Conditional compilation is the process of compiling conditionally-compiled source code.
paragraphs.fls_pf1v89h7pjhh: A construct subject to attribute cfg where the related configuration predicate evaluates to false is not considered part of a Rust program.
paragraphs.fls_y56RGw3cbFex: A crate root module subject to attribute cfg where the related configuration predicate evaluates to false is considered empty except for all [attribute]s up to the invoked attribute cfg.
paragraphs.fls_h6b1fuw4nvi1: An attribute cfg_attr where the related configuration predicate evaluates to false is not considered part of a Rust program.

sections.title: Program Entry Point
sections.content:
Program Entry Point

A program entry point is a function that is invoked at the start of
a Rust program.

A main function signature is a function signature subject to the
following restrictions:

* It lacks [function qualifier]s async and unsafe,

* Its ABI is Rust,

* It lacks [generic parameter]s,

* It lacks [function parameter]s,

* It lacks a return type,

* It lacks a where clause,

* It has a function body.

paragraphs.fls_dp64b08em9BJ: A program entry point is a function that is invoked at the start of a Rust program.
paragraphs.fls_sbGnkm8Ephiu: A main function signature is a function signature subject to the following restrictions:
paragraphs.fls_o4fxok23134r: It lacks [function qualifier]s async and unsafe,
